title: Fintech: Understanding Fintech advantages
description: differences between traditional and fin-tech approaches

cover_slide_data.heading: Understanding Fintech advantages
cover_slide_data.intro: Lets join technological rebellion in finance

cover_slide_data.heading: Understanding Fintech advantages
cover_slide_data.intro: Lets join technological rebellion in finance

published_attributes.title: Learning Plan
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Reasoning

The goal of this course is to instill in you boldness of technology rebels, out of box thinking and habit of looking beyond schemas whenever work with Fintechs.

The method to achieve that is to present you how Fintechs have already changed modern finance. You will be presented the technological disruption others made. By that you will find that doing Fintech projects at Neguru you can demolish status quo in financial sector and become true technological rebel.

E-learning outcomes:

  • understanding difference between traditional finance and Fintech approach
  • Knowing examples of how Fintechs already changes finance
  • To get eager to change finance even more

published_attributes.title: How to read the course
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Each sections is divided in 2 parts
    • Legacy approach - what was original service before fintechs changes it
    • Fintech case study - what was the change that fintech brought us?
  • Fintech technologies are very often implemented in traditional institutions or even created by them. Do not mistake old fashion institution with legacy approach

blocks.text: Each sections is divided in 2 parts
Legacy approach - what was original service before fintechs changes it
Fintech case study - what was the change that fintech brought us?
Fintech technologies are very often implemented in traditional institutions or even created by them. Do not mistake old fashion institution with legacy approach

published_attributes.title: Authentication
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Legacy approach:

  • Face to face verification 

Fintech case study:

  • 2f authentication from independent sources
  • First factor for login, 2nd for confirmation of high risk actions as transferring money, pairs examples: 
    • Web access login/pass & application push 
    • App access & sms

Read more about fintechs specialised in this approach:

  • twilio solution for financial services
  • Google Authenticator

published_attributes.title: Onboarding - KYC
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Assure the user is who he claim to be
  • Avoid fraudsters, terrorists etc
  • Require to hold huge database related to world-wide embargo lists, document verification and document-to-person verification mechanism

Legacy approach:

  • Face to face verification 

Fin-Tech case study:

  • Sophisticated AI algorithms to automatically verify documents and cross check selfie with provided document or back office with people checking documents by person (most cases)

Read more about fintechs specialised in this approach:

  • au10tix
  • veriff

published_attributes.title: Transferring money
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Legacy approach: - Wire transfer

  • Highly regulated
  • Require integration with interbank money transfer system/ institution as KIR (Poland), SWIFT (GLOBAL) or Fedwire (US)
  • Require IBAN and BIC numbers issued by local supervision authority (in most cases local central bank)

Fintech case study - Peer-to-peer money transfer

  • Require accounts in multiple banks with significant cash deposits in each to create internal transfer network
  • simplified example
    • There are 2 banks: Bank A and Bank B in both we have bank accounts with own cash
    • 100 users want to make transfer from Bank A to Bank B
    • Instead of making actual transfer we collect money from each user at bank A (using fact that transfer inside banks are in most cases free of charge) and provide money at bank B (from our previously created cash deposit)
    • At the end of a day we make a single bank transfer with all money collected at Bank A to Bank B so to restore balances to initial values. Users pay fees for each operation we conduct but we pay bank transfer fee only once

Read more about fintechs specialised in this approach:

  • TransferWise
  • PayU

published_attributes.title: Deposits
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Keeping money deposits of our users 
  • highly regulated
  • We need to prove to supervision authority the security of deposits (usually by making significant cash deposit at central bank to guarantee repayment in case of bankruptcy
  • Any actions related to money inside our institution (transfers, making loans or deposits etc) have to be reflected in our database in accordance with highly regulated standards.
  • In accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (US GAAP) in US or International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in rest of the world
  • In the EU deposits can be held by Electric Money Institutions, Payment Institutions and Banks. In the rest of world service is usually limited to banks

Legacy approach - Bank deposits

  • Vast majority of money entrusted to bank as deposit are transfer as a credit to other bank customer
  • In 2021 European Banks had to keep only 1-2% of cash entrusted as deposits (Reserve Requirement Ratio)

Fintech case study - e-wallets 

  • Use special licence (Electronic Money Institution in EU) or use mass collect accounts provided by commercial banks (as a white label)

Read more about fintechs specialised in this approach:

  • Google Pay
  • Apple Pay

published_attributes.title: Payment cards
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Card is payment gateway linked to the account
  • Card transactions operate in a similar manner to wire transfers where transfers are conducted with card payment system providers (MasterCard, American Express etc.) 
  • Require a long list of integrations (authorisations, clearing, settlements, card printer etc.)
  • In most cases process takes approx 1 year due to duration of internal procedures of card system  

Old fashioned approach:

  • Card users can not monitor transactions, there is no customer interface
  • Customers receive expenses summary at the end of month in paper version (general practise in US)

Legacy study:

  • User interfaces with current transactions provided on web and/ or mobile app
  • Ability to issue or manage current card from customer dashboard

Read more about fintechs specialised in this approach:

  • N26
  • Revolut
